messages.content: Data availability seems to be one of the core issues in MINA blockchain. This post aims at collecting all the relevant information about the issues and challenges of data availability.

To have a concrete understanding of what it means, let’s take an example of NFT. For ERC-721 like NFT standard, it must have a mapping of owners, allowances and balances. Although there seem to exist projects such as Comdex/nft-app https://github.com/comdex/nft-zkapp and orkunkilic/MinaFT https://github.com/orkunkilic/MinaFT , both of these projects make assumptions on having an off chain solution where the data is stored in entirety and the commitment to the data is stored as a state on chain.

embeds.description: Contribute to Comdex/nft-zkapp development by creating an account on GitHub.

embeds.title: GitHub - orkunkilic/MinaFT: ETH Amsterdam -> 3rd Best Use Mina Prot...
embeds.description: ETH Amsterdam -> 3rd Best Use Mina Protocol. Contribute to orkunkilic/MinaFT development by creating an account on GitHub.

messages.content: Although off-chain solutions have been discussed in https://docs.minaprotocol.com/zkapps/tutorials/offchain-storage , it provides details on how only a single-server architecture works.

embeds.title: Mina Documentation
embeds.description: Website for documentation about Mina Protocol

messages.content:
Coming back to NFT application (assuming there exists an off chain mapping storage), user A holds an NFT #1. 
User A wants to transfer the NFT #1 to User B.

The way I imagine this to work is:
User A creates a Merkle Proof (using offchain data) showing that he/she indeed owns the NFT #1 and is properly updating the Merkle root of the following mappings: 
1. `owners`: Change the owner of #1 to User B.
2. `allowances`: Change the allowances of #1 to None.
3. `balances`: Decrease the balance of User A by 1 and increase the balance of User B by 1.

User B now owns #1 and can transfer it to say User C.

Now, let’s consider the case where there are three users A, B, C owning NFTs #1 #2 #3 respectively.

Suppose:
Tx1: A wants to transfer #1 to B.
Tx2: B wants to transfer #2 to C.
Tx3: C wants to transfer #3 to A.

Since all three users will have access to the same off chain storage, all three can create the proofs. However, only those transactions will be valid in a block, since once a transaction is included and the state is updated, the preconditions for Tx2 and Tx3 will have changed. 

If there were 1000 transactions on the same contract, only 1 of those transactions will pass.

One way to avoid this is by using a sequencer. Sequencer is going to update it such that the preconditions for the 999 transactions after Tx1 is based on the output of Tx1, Tx2, ....  and so on.

Even with the sequencer, we have to rely on the sequencer to act as a data availability layer. If the sequencer goes offline, no transaction can be made on that program.

One design issue to consider with sequencer is, do we allow users to make transactions directly on L1 without a sequencer. If this is indeed a case, then the user can update the state, but not reveal the changes made. 

To concretize what I mean, suppose User A wants to transfer NFT #1 to User B. User A can create a proof and updates to the on-chain states. But what if User A does not reveal User B address. In that case, the merkle root is updated without knowing what the new merkle leaf is.
In this case, the whole application collapses, as other users will not be able to make transactions since they cannot construct the whole tree.
we’ve built ZKFS for this purpose exactly! https://zkfs.io/blog/introducing-zkfs-mina-data-availability-layer

embeds.title: Introducing ZKFS, Mina's native data availability layer | ZKFS
embeds.description: Introducing ZKFS _(Zero-Knowledge File System)_ - a data availability layer designed to reduce blockchain storage requirements while still allowing for complex business logic.

messages.content: and to adress the second half of the problem, @rpanic is working on an L2 solution as well

Hi @maht0rz, thanks for the quicky reply.
In your architecture, how do you validate that a piece of data has been written in storage? (referencing the figma design?)

Nodes responsible for storing the data, apply data write requests to their trees, therefore they should have all the data present - which allows them to build the tree to match a root hash thats part of the on-chain storage of a smart contract, we call this 'the consensus'
This solution inherits certain characteristics and drawbacks of the L1, which you've touched upon yourself. Thats why we're working on an L2 solution currently - to address those 🙂
Just to be on the same page, the drawback is that the user can update the state directly and thus make the data unavailable?
No, with the design of ZKFS, the raw data writes are available in L1 archive nodes, therefore can be reconstructed easily.

From what I understand, we can update the state directly, right? If the given `updates`  matches with the `preconditions` and `proof`.
In such case, L1 archive nodes will not have access to what was changed exactly.
Like in the example above, we can update the root of `owners` mapping but do not reveal the leaf of the `owners`. In that case, L1 archive nodes will not have access to the updated leaf, right?
Yes, you can do that, but we choose not to and we publish the changed leaves as part of the transaction as well
And if the adversary decides to do that, have you guys thought on ways to mitigate that?
because it's not compulsory that the changed leaves are also part of the transaction right? or do we / can we make it compulsory?
it is compulsory
oh! can you point to the resources on how it can be made compulsory? I had the idea that all the inputs were private.
sure, you have to look into account updates and events 🙂

In regards to token and token-like objects (NFTs etc), I woul recommend you to take a look at Minas native token and token account, which is certainly different from other token implementations like ERC-20

I understand events are part of the transaction. 

I want to understand if it's possible to modify the data inside the event and still have the proof verified or is it something that that's impossible.
i.e.  I do the following steps:
1. Create a tx.
2. Manually update the events field in tx. 
3. Create a proof for the tx
4. Send the tx object with proof. 

In this case, will the protocol accept my transaction or will it be rejected?
create a tx & prove a tx are basically identical steps, you're proving the creation of the events themselves, so within the proof they cant be tampered with

I thought creating a transaction object and proving the transaction were two distinct steps:
1. When we create a tx object, we simply populate all the fields
2. When we create prove, we generate proof for the tx object we just created.

Also, I thought the creation of events were not the part of the proof. They were just some arbitrary data.

its like you say, but the proof carries what is known as public input, so that when the arbitrary data is being used, it can be checked against the proof to ensure it was really created as part of the proven computation
What else are public inputs in a proof? I know the `appstate` is always the public input, `events` are also public inputs as you said. Are there other public inputs as well?
there's a few things, its best to read the zk apps MIP for an in depth overview of how the system works:https://github.com/MinaProtocol/MIPs/blob/main/MIPS/mip-zkapps.md

messages.content: Thanks @maht0rz . Really appreciate it!

This was indeed a good read. 

I finished reading through this and I still am not sure if events are part of the proof.
https://github.com/MinaProtocol/MIPs/blob/main/MIPS/mip-zkapps.md#zkapp-transactions covers what are the information in account updates and `events` and `actions` seem to be a part of it. But I could not explicitly find if `events` and `events` are part of the public inputs to the circuit.

Are there other resources that goes into what components are part of the public inputs to the proof?

messages.content: Continuing with the discussion, a sequencer seems to be required for every application that might require two updates in the single block right?
Also @maht0rz how do you guarantee that all the MINA events have been caught in ZKFS? Also, how will others verify if the events added to ZKFS were actually part of MINA tx that is on chain.

Great discussion, I want to add that our docs also have an explanation @ account update as public input https://docs.minaprotocol.com/zkapps/snarkyjs/interact-with-mina#creating-proofs-and-what-they-mean
I wouldn't say so, good zkApp designs would use actions to enable concurrent user interactions and would roll up actions into a state update every now & then

Actually this is what @Comdex does in the NFT example repo you linked, I recommend to study that code, it's very high quality
https://github.com/comdex/nft-zkapp

@Prajwol G I want to address your question, "how can I know what parts of the account update are part of the proof"
the source of truth is this auto-generated file where the account update type is defined:
https://github.com/o1-labs/snarkyjs-bindings/blob/18b4f136b28550984886468b0560c3e857f57dbf/mina-transaction/gen/transaction.ts#L317
The account update type consists mostly of "provable types" like Bool, UInt32, etc. To a first approximation, all of these will be part of the public input. Then, there are a few plain JS types on it, like `number` and `string`. These won't be part of the public input.

However, actually some of the subtypes have their own special `Provable<T>` implementation which restricts what part of it becomes a public input. For example, there is a custom `Event` type, where the type is
```ts
events: { data: Field[][]; hash: Field; }
```
the custom provable is ultimately implemented here: 
https://github.com/o1-labs/snarkyjs/blob/63fa38d79207b0d1b74c149b21598389352a8688/src/lib/events.ts#L125

and you see that is has
```ts
toFields({ hash }) {
  return [hash];
},
```
which means that actually only the `hash` is how this type is represented in provable code.

if you push events, you will hash them all as part of your provable code, and the hash becomes part of the provable account update type. this account update will then also be hashed in your provable code, and finally, this hash is one of the two field elements that make up the zkapp public input.

the reason for these extra hashing steps before making something part of the public input is that they give you static sized types. events can have any size, but the account update type that they are part of is static sized

I guess the summary is, we carefully designed the protocol so that all of our "smart contract functionality" like events is adequately represented as part of a zk proof. And, if you want to know how exactly that is done, docs are lacking but you can always find out with some digging or asking

Hey all. Quick question for @maht0rz,  the solution that you have provided is meant for the problem mentioned at https://docs.minaprotocol.com/zkapps/tutorials/offchain-storage
Or it targets some other aspect of Mina? Thank you : ) Amazing project though kudos  🎉
